By STEVE YOST
. Starting next fall, the UniverintY Will sponsor the Blue Cross
Hospital Health Insurance plan to
all undergraduates and any other
interested persons.
Gene Zernsky's Student Council

,

Committee has released a tentative Policy which will go into effect in September. However the
Plan will only go into operation
H 50% or more of the student
body sign up for it.
Rates
The cost for single persons will
be either $1.25 a month or a flat
rate of $15.00 a year. The yearly
rate will cover the policy holder
from September to September and
113 Payable at the beginning of the
school year.
This insurance will cover any
sort of injury or operation to the
Person involved, excluding maternity benefits.
For married people the rate is
$2.50 a month or $30.00 a year,
also without maternity benefits.
Married Policy
The other policy for married
Persons includes children under
19 years of age and maternity.
This will cost $3.20 a month or
$38.40 per year.
More information will be released later on this term both
from the Blue Cross Company
and from Dr. Frank R. Smith of
the Student Health Clinic. Bulletins will be sent to the incoping
freshman class.

St. Valentine's Day will furnish
the Sweetheart theme for the annual Sophomore-Freshman Dance,
to be held tonight from nine till
one in the Main Ball Room of the
Alcazar, Cathedral and Madison
Streets.
Admission to the dance will be
$2.40, with formal dress and corsages optional. Tickets will be on
sale at the door.
Chambers Plays
Rivers Chambers' Orchestra, a
popular local group, will provide
music for the affair.
The Booster Club will sell refreshments, consisting of set-ups
and soft drinks.
Bill Corbin, of Lhe sophomore
class, and Charlie Peinado, freshman representative,- are co-chairmen. Peinado is in charge of table
reservations.

By AL N. EPSTEIN

Beeause of a "Combination of unfortunate eireumstanees,"
the Barnstormers have been forced to make drmtic- revisions in
their plans for the current season.

Now is the time of year when a
committee from ODK. honorary
activities fraternity, starts the
selection for their annual freshman award.
This honor is one of the fel,
means of recognizing outstanding
individuals in the freshman class.
The award is presented in two
categories; one for the most out-c
standing freshman athlete, the
other for the freshman most actively engaged in extra-curricular
activities.
The presentation is made at the
ODK banquet which is held in the
spring, usually in May.
The first step .in the selection
is a careful perusal of the records
of all the freshmen by a committee. The committee selects the
top twenty-five or so candidates.
To aid in the preliminary sorting out, a point system is employed. Point values are assigned
the various sports and activities
and a rough score is compiled for
each man.
After the top twenty-five have
been determined, their names are
(Continued on Page f)

Dr. Henry T. Rowell will serve
as Chief Marshall for the Convocation.
School Closed
Dr. Bronk today issued a special invitation to all Hopkins students and their friends to attend
the Convocation this year. School
will be closed all day in observance of the anniversary.

Grad Dance I
Graduate students will hold a
square dance on Friday, February
22nd. The event wilt. be held in
the ROTC building from 9 P. M. to
1 A. M. The public is invited.
Tickets will be $1.20 including
tax, and since a large turnout is
expected, those interested may obtain tickets from Graduate Student
ReAssociation representatives.
freshments will be served at the
dance.

Debate Tourney Termed
Success, Princeton Wins
The 2nd Annual Debate Tournament sponsored by the Johns
Hopkins Debate Society was considered quite a success by all
the persons who represented the
24 universities and colleges which
attended, during the mid term
vacation period,
Each team debated the national
debate topic, "Resolved: That the
Federal Government Should Adopt
a Permawmt Program of Wage
and Price Controls." Princeton
and South Carolina were pitted in
the final run-off debate and Princeton was judged the winner thus
taking the big new trophy sponsored by the JHU debaters back
to New Jersey with theni.
South Carolina placed second
and Loyola College of Baltimore
was third. The Johns Hopkins

team did not participate in any
part of the program. They acted
merely as hosts to the visitors.
Though the tournament was primarily a debate affair its sidelight.
an extemporaneous speaking contest drew quite a bit of attention
from the local press. The Suitpapers ga.ve the contest a six
column, seven picture spread. Each
entrant had 15 minutes to think
over a choice of four topics. He
spoke on one of these for five
minutes. Notre Dame's John DeCrane won first place in this event
and very appropriately spoke on
"Collegiate Athletics."
A banquet followed the final debate. Dean G. Wilson Shaffer
awarded the first place trophy to
Vie Sidel and Chris Webber a
Princeton at that time.

A SMALL BUT POSITIVE REVISION
On or before March 15 each student at Johns 'Hopkins who
held part time employment during .1951 will be required to
file an income tax report.
Throughout the country a high percentage of college men
and women are earning all or part of the funds necessary to
pay their college. expenses. While the price of higher learning
is increasing—while this obstacle to its acquisition bulges—more
and more of our population thirst for it.
There can be no disagreement over the fact that an educated,
intelligent nation is morally and mentally stronger than one whose
people are not given the opportunity of securing the benefits of
college attendance.

Research and development work in
chemical engineering often overlap
at Du Pont, except where the research is fundamental.
The chemical engineer occupied
with fundamental research is chiefly
concerned with basic studies of unit
operations and processes involving
reaction kinetics, thermodynamic
properties of fluids, high-pressure
techniques,equilibrium studies, heat
transfer and the like. Such studies
often lead to lower-cost manufacturing processes. Some recent projects
in fundamental research have been:
1. A study of fluidized catalyst reaction units including degree offluid ation, temperature uniformity, catalyst activity and life, and conversion
of feed gases.

2. Studies of the fundamental transfer relations between phases, for instance, gas and liquid, in reacting
materials.
Apart from the chemical engineers
engaged in fundamental research,

there are many groups working in
applied research and development.
In fact, this is the major part of the
chemical engineering work done at
Du Pont. Here are examples of the
literally hundreds of unusual problems They have solved:
1. Designing equipment for producing pure silicon at 1000°C.(Though
one of the starting compounds is
highly corrosive, only spectroscopic
traces ofimpurities can be tolerated.)
2. Developing a high-pressure liquidphase process to replace the standard dry method of producing sodium
azide formerly employed.
3. Designing a continuous flow, gasliquid reactor for use in making a
fiber intermediate under pressure.
4. Developing, from laboratory research results, a process for largescale production of complex polymeric materials used in the manufacture of color photographic film.
These examples can only hint the
variety and originality of problems

constantly arising at Du Pont. They
indicate the challenge as well as the
broad opportunity awaiting the talents and ingenuity of the young
chemical engineer who wants a career in research and development.

. Starting next fall, the UniverintY Will sponsor the Blue Cross
Hospital Health Insurance plan to
all undergraduates and any other
interested persons.
Gene Zernsky's Student Council

,

Committee has released a tentative Policy which will go into effect in September. However the
Plan will only go into operation
H 50% or more of the student
body sign up for it.
Rates
The cost for single persons will
be either $1.25 a month or a flat
rate of $15.00 a year. The yearly
rate will cover the policy holder
from September to September and
113 Payable at the beginning of the
school year.
This insurance will cover any
sort of injury or operation to the
Person involved, excluding maternity benefits.
For married people the rate is
$2.50 a month or $30.00 a year,
also without maternity benefits.
Married Policy
The other policy for married
Persons includes children under
19 years of age and maternity.
This will cost $3.20 a month or
$38.40 per year.
More information will be released later on this term both
from the Blue Cross Company
and from Dr. Frank R. Smith of
the Student Health Clinic. Bulletins will be sent to the incoping
freshman class.

St. Valentine's Day will furnish
the Sweetheart theme for the annual Sophomore-Freshman Dance,
to be held tonight from nine till
one in the Main Ball Room of the
Alcazar, Cathedral and Madison
Streets.
Admission to the dance will be
$2.40, with formal dress and corsages optional. Tickets will be on
sale at the door.
Chambers Plays
Rivers Chambers' Orchestra, a
popular local group, will provide
music for the affair.
The Booster Club will sell refreshments, consisting of set-ups
and soft drinks.
Bill Corbin, of Lhe sophomore
class, and Charlie Peinado, freshman representative,- are co-chairmen. Peinado is in charge of table
reservations.

Now is the time of year when a
committee from ODK. honorary
activities fraternity, starts the
selection for their annual freshman award.
This honor is one of the fel,
means of recognizing outstanding
individuals in the freshman class.
The award is presented in two
categories; one for the most out-c
standing freshman athlete, the
other for the freshman most actively engaged in extra-curricular
activities.
The presentation is made at the
ODK banquet which is held in the
spring, usually in May.
The first step .in the selection
is a careful perusal of the records
of all the freshmen by a committee. The committee selects the
top twenty-five or so candidates.
To aid in the preliminary sorting out, a point system is employed. Point values are assigned
the various sports and activities
and a rough score is compiled for
each man.
After the top twenty-five have
been determined, their names are
(Continued on Page f)

as Chief Marshall for the Convocation.
School Closed
Dr. Bronk today issued a special invitation to all Hopkins students and their friends to attend
the Convocation this year. School
will be closed all day in observance of the anniversary.

Grad Dance I
Graduate students will hold a
square dance on Friday, February
22nd. The event wilt. be held in
the ROTC building from 9 P. M. to
1 A. M. The public is invited.
Tickets will be $1.20 including
tax, and since a large turnout is
expected, those interested may obtain tickets from Graduate Student
ReAssociation representatives.
freshments will be served at the

Debate Tourney Termed
Success, Princeton Wins
The 2nd Annual Debate Tournament sponsored by the Johns
Hopkins Debate Society was considered quite a success by all
the persons who represented the
24 universities and colleges which
attended, during the mid term
vacation period,
Each team debated the national
debate topic, "Resolved: That the
Federal Government Should Adopt
a Permawmt Program of Wage
and Price Controls." Princeton
and South Carolina were pitted in
the final run-off debate and Princeton was judged the winner thus
taking the big new trophy sponsored by the JHU debaters back
to New Jersey with theni.
South Carolina placed second
and Loyola College of Baltimore
was third. The Johns Hopkins

team did not participate in any
part of the program. They acted
merely as hosts to the visitors.
Though the tournament was primarily a debate affair its sidelight.
an extemporaneous speaking contest drew quite a bit of attention
from the local press. The Suitpapers ga.ve the contest a six
column, seven picture spread. Each
entrant had 15 minutes to think
over a choice of four topics. He
spoke on one of these for five
minutes. Notre Dame's John DeCrane won first place in this event
and very appropriately spoke on
"Collegiate Athletics."
A banquet followed the final debate. Dean G. Wilson Shaffer
awarded the first place trophy to
Vie Sidel and Chris Webber a
Princeton at that time.

A SMALL BUT POSITIVE REVISION
On or before March 15 each student at Johns 'Hopkins who
held part time employment during .1951 will be required to
file an income tax report.
Throughout the country a high percentage of college men
and women are earning all or part of the funds necessary to
pay their college. expenses. While the price of higher learning
is increasing—while this obstacle to its acquisition bulges—more
and more of our population thirst for it.
There can be no disagreement over the fact that an educated,
intelligent nation is morally and mentally stronger than one whose
people are not given the opportunity of securing the benefits of
college attendance.

Research and development work in
chemical engineering often overlap
at Du Pont, except where the research is fundamental.
The chemical engineer occupied
with fundamental research is chiefly
concerned with basic studies of unit
operations and processes involving
reaction kinetics, thermodynamic
properties of fluids, high-pressure
techniques,equilibrium studies, heat
transfer and the like. Such studies
often lead to lower-cost manufacturing processes. Some recent projects
in fundamental research have been:
1. A study of fluidized catalyst reaction units including degree offluid ation, temperature uniformity, catalyst activity and life, and conversion
of feed gases.

2. Studies of the fundamental transfer relations between phases, for instance, gas and liquid, in reacting
materials.
Apart from the chemical engineers
engaged in fundamental research,

there are many groups working in
applied research and development.
In fact, this is the major part of the
chemical engineering work done at
Du Pont. Here are examples of the
literally hundreds of unusual problems They have solved:
1. Designing equipment for producing pure silicon at 1000°C.(Though
one of the starting compounds is
highly corrosive, only spectroscopic
traces ofimpurities can be tolerated.)
2. Developing a high-pressure liquidphase process to replace the standard dry method of producing sodium
azide formerly employed.
3. Designing a continuous flow, gasliquid reactor for use in making a
fiber intermediate under pressure.
4. Developing, from laboratory research results, a process for largescale production of complex polymeric materials used in the manufacture of color photographic film.
These examples can only hint the
variety and originality of problems

constantly arising at Du Pont. They
indicate the challenge as well as the
broad opportunity awaiting the talents and ingenuity of the young
chemical engineer who wants a career in research and development.
